Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: The carpenter should maintain a clean and organized work area
Story: I was sweeping up the sawdust in the workshop, making sure every tool was in its place. My boss always reminded me that a cluttered workspace was an accident waiting to happen, and I took pride in keeping things safe and tidy. Just as I was about to put away the last hammer, I glanced out the open door and saw my stepbrother, Jamie, on the sidewalk. He was fiddling with his phone, not paying attention, and started to step off the curb into the street. My heart jumped—cars sped down this road all the time. I knew I should drop everything and call out, maybe even run after him. But the floor was scattered with nails and boards, and if I left it like this, someone could get hurt, maybe even me. I felt torn, the weight of responsibility pressing from both sides—my duty to keep the site safe, and my promise to always look out for Jamie. My hands shook as I hesitated, caught between the two worlds that demanded all of me at once.
